<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 361, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2023 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 606]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 220, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 712, 907, 840]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 867, 727, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 16 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 740, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 757, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium position of a metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 133, 574, 152]]<|/det|>
Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 158, 871, 592]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 607, 532, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 640, 178, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 640, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
Adjust the height of the boss and the position of the weight W on the bench so that the metre rule is parallel to the bench and both springs are vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 176, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 918, 103]]<|/det|>
Slide the rubber band and slotted mass onto the rule so that the rubber band is approximately \(30 \text{cm}\) from the end of the rule. The rule will tilt down, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 178, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 119, 660, 136]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of W so that both springs are vertical.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 144, 831, 580]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 592, 534, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 624, 175, 641]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 623, 920, 641]]<|/det|>
The distance between the rubber band and the end of the rule is \(x\), as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 655, 384, 672]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 701, 917, 718]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 178, 750]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 732, 910, 750]]<|/det|>
The angle indicated by the plumb-line on the protractor scale is \(\theta\), as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 763, 384, 780]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 808, 920, 826]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) ...........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 825, 920, 843]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Vary \(x\) by moving the rubber band along the metre rule. Adjust the position of W so that both springs are vertical. Measure \(x\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 576, 135]]<|/det|>
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(x\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 707, 166]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\cos \theta\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 143, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 583, 176, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 583, 670, 602]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\cos \theta\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(x\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 180, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 615, 457, 632]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 615, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 645, 183, 664]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 645, 608, 664]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 845, 917, 863]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 876, 917, 895]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 893, 920, 911]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 722, 91]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the quantities \(\theta\) and \(x\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 102, 559, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\cos \theta = ax + b\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 398, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 672, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your answers in **(c)**(iii), determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 346, 197]]<|/det|>
Give appropriate units.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 319, 917, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>a = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>b = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 396, 873, 415]]<|/det|>
For this experiment, the constant \(a\) is related to the spring constant \(S\) of each spring by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 421, 536, 450]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\frac{\rho}{S}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 348, 476]]<|/det|>
where \(p = 13.15 \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 576, 508]]<|/det|>
Determine the value of \(S\). Give an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 643, 922, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>S = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 20]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 72, 610, 89]]<|/det|>
● Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 97, 771, 621]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 664, 212, 682]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 664, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
Pass the string through the slot of the slotted mass and tie it to the tube, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 710, 212, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 710, 920, 743]]<|/det|>
Hook the mass hanger onto the other end of the string and then adjust the height of the boss until the mass hanger is just touching the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 215, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Rotate the slotted mass and tube 16 times so that the string is wound around the tube, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 112, 759, 470]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 529, 566, 632]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 648, 534, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 679, 215, 696]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 678, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
Release the slotted mass and take measurements to determine the time \(T\) for the mass hanger to reach the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 817, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ............................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 541, 90]]<|/det|>
You are provided with modelling clay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 102, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Using **all** the modelling clay, roll the modelling clay into a long cylinder and bend it to form a ring around the outside of the slotted mass, as shown in Fig. 2.4. Ensure it is securely attached to the slotted mass.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 160, 755, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 397, 534, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 428, 215, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 428, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the outside diameter \(D_{2}\) of the ring of modelling clay, as shown in Fig. 2.4.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>D_2 = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 181, 633]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 615, 824, 633]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(D_{2}\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 769, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 344, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculate C using

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 92, 611, 123]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{C} = M_{1}D_{1}^{2} + \frac{M_{2}(D_{2} + D_{1})^{2}}{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 371, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(M_2 = 0.070 \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 303, 922, 322]]<|/det|>
<form>C = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 335, 180, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 335, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
● Rotate the slotted mass and tube 16 times so that the string is wound around the tube, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
● Release the slotted mass and take measurements to determine the time \(T\) for the mass hanger to reach the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 518, 922, 537]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ........................................................ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 611, 90]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(T\) and C is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 101, 536, 120]]<|/det|>
\[T^{2} = kC\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 339, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 507, 183]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 350, 917, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 427, 146, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 751, 445]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(15\%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 828, 477]]<|/det|>
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(c)**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[856, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
